title: Publications
text:
Persistent and anti-Persistent Motion in Bounded and Unbounded Space: Resolution of the First-Passage Problem 
Authors: D.M., Luca Giuggioli
Journal: New Journal of Physics, 26, (2024)
Summary:
Here we present an exact analytic framework to quantify search processes with for the one-step memory perisistent random walk. The theory is general and applicable in arbitrary dimension, with any boundary condition. This may find application in active matter, mathematical biology and movement ecology.



Here we uncovered the existence of bi-modal first-passage probality mass functions in bounded (reflecting and periodic) persistent random walks.





Multi-target search in bounded andheterogeneous environments: a lattice random walk perspective
Authors: Luca Giuggioli, Seeralan Sarvaharman, Debraj Das, D.M. and Toby Kay
Journal: To Appear in The Target Problem (Eds. D. S. Grebenkov, R. Metzler, G. Oshanin), Springer Nature (2024)
Summary:
Here we present a review of the latest advances in the field of search in heterogeneous and bounded lattice random walks. It was an absolute pleasure to work with such a lovely team.



A collection of first-passage probability mass functions for hexagonal and square lattices with and without bias.





Exact spatiotemporal dynamics of lattice random walks in hexagonal and honeycomb domains
Authors: D.M., Seeralan Sarvaharman and Luca Giuggioli
Journal: Physical Review E, 107, 054139, (2023)
Summary:
Here we develop a general theory to exactly describe diffusive processes in hexagonal geometries. We consider two lattices, the coordination number six hexagonal lattice and the non-Bravias coordination number three honeycomb lattice. Random movement on hexagonal structures is seen as a modelling tool in varying applications from exciton transport on the surface of carbon nanotubes, to animal foraging theory.



The diffusive propagation over a six-sided hexagon with zig-zag periodic boundary condition for the honeycomb lattice.

title: About
text:
I am a statistical physicist in the final year of my PhD in the lab of Prof. Luca Giuggioli at the University of Bristol. Before that I completed an MEng in Engineering Mathematics at the University of Bristol.
In general, I am interested in non-equilibrium statistical physics, with a key interest in developing new theory for discrete search processes. My research output is generally mathematical, however to supplement this I write many stochastic simulations. With this, I am interested in the fast implementation of stochastic simulations, with my programming language of choice being Julia.
